messages.text: What is it called when you identify the smallest change to a set of contraints that it would take for a feasible solution to exist?

elements.text: What is it called when you identify the smallest change to a set of contraints that it would take for a feasible solution to exist?

messages.text: Other than extremely difficult.

elements.text: Other than extremely difficult.

messages.text: The closest I can think of is the « irreducible infeasible system », which is a minimal (wrt inclusion) set of constraints that renders the problem infeasible. Irreducible means that if you remove one of those constraints, the IIS is no longer infeasible.

elements.text: The closest I can think of is the « irreducible infeasible system », which is a minimal (wrt inclusion) set of constraints that renders the problem infeasible. Irreducible means that if you remove one of those constraints, the IIS is no longer infeasible.

messages.text: There may be several disconnected IIS though

elements.text: There may be several disconnected IIS though

messages.text: Maybe closer to your setting is a « phase-I »-like approach: add slacks to your constraints, and minimize the slack. If the result is zero you have a feasible point, other wise it tells you how much you need to relax the constraints to get a feasible solution.

elements.text: Maybe closer to your setting is a « phase-I »-like approach: add slacks to your constraints, and minimize the slack. If the result is zero you have a feasible point, other wise it tells you how much you need to relax the constraints to get a feasible solution.

A particular special case of this is dealing with conflicts in Pkg.
What is the smallest number of packages I can edit to solve them

elements.text:
A particular special case of this is dealing with conflicts in Pkg.
What is the smallest number of packages I can edit to solve them

messages.text: For that you can add a "slack" version for each package which is compatible with everything else, and then minimize the number of slack versions used.

text.text: For that you can add a "slack" version for each package which is compatible with everything else, and then minimize the number of slack versions used.

messages.text: @/all NSF is funding @odow's work on JuMP: <https://jump.dev/announcements/2021/02/22/agreement/>. We will discuss and answer questions during the monthly developer call on Thursday.

attachments.title: NumFOCUS signs agreement with MIT to provide ongoing maintenance and support
attachments.text: The JuMP Steering Committee is pleased to announce that we, through NumFOCUS, have signed an agreement with MIT to providing ongoing maintenance and support of JuMP as part of the National Science Foundation award OAC1835443. The agreement may be renewed on an annual basis through December 2023. At a high-level, the agreement covers work that is focused on improving the long-term sustainability of the JuMP ecosystem. The work is intentionally focused on tasks that people are unlikely to want to do on a volunteer basis, or that require deep technical knowledge of JuMP and MathOptInterface internals. This includes things such as: Fixing long-open GitHub issues (e.g., improving documentation, and usability improvements). Maintaining code health, including readability, addressing gaps in testing, and reducing technical debt. Maintaining wrappers for open-source solvers in the JuMP-dev GitHub organization. The things not covered by the agreement are: Maintenance of wrappers for commercial solvers such as CPLEX, Gurobi, and Xpress. While we are conscious of the potential side effects of bringing paid contributors into an open source community, our hope is that by focusing our paid effort on these tasks that promote long-term sustainability, we can make it easier both for new volunteer contributors to join the project and for our highly valued existing contributors to develop the features they are interested in. The first person being funded is Dr. Oscar Dowson, a core contributor to JuMP, and also a member of the Steering Committee. Oscar will be working on a part-time basis of three days per week. His first key tasks are improving the JuMP and MathOptInterface documentation, and finishing tasks on the roadmap for a JuMP 1.0 release. Funding paid developers is a big step for JuMP, but one that we believe sets it up for a sustainable, long-term future. Miles Lubin, Joey Huchette, and Changhyun Kwon (Per our conflict of interest policy, Oscar, who is funded by the grant, and Juan Pablo Vielma, who is a co-PI of the NSF grant, recused themselves from Steering Committee votes on this agreement.)
attachments.fallback: JuMP: NumFOCUS signs agreement with MIT to provide ongoing maintenance and support

messages.text:
Quick question: any chance that `add_NL_expression(m, expr) = JuMP.NonlinearExpression(m, JuMP._NonlinearExprData(m, expr))` can work, or is correct?

We already have `add_NL_constraint` as the non macro version of `@NLconstraint`, and I would like a similar non macro version of `@NLexpression`, so that I can add a non linear expression from a normal Julia expression tree to a JuMP.jl model, as if I had constructed that expression via `@NLexpression`.

elements.text: Quick question: any chance that
add_NL_expression(m, expr) = JuMP.NonlinearExpression(m, JuMP._NonlinearExprData(m, expr))

can work, or is correct?

messages.text: I'd like to have the equivalent of `add_NL_constraint`, but for `@NLexpression`. So essentially I'm trying to have `add_NL_expression` as a no macro version of `@NLexpression`. Initially I thought that maybe `add_NL_expression(m, expr) = JuMP.NonlinearExpression(m, JuMP._NonlinearExprData(m, expr))` could do the trick, but that probably is not correct? Any pointers how I might go about this?

text.text: I'd like to have the equivalent of `add_NL_constraint`, but for `@NLexpression`. So essentially I'm trying to have `add_NL_expression` as a no macro version of `@NLexpression`. Initially I thought that maybe `add_NL_expression(m, expr) = JuMP.NonlinearExpression(m, JuMP._NonlinearExprData(m, expr))` could do the trick, but that probably is not correct? Any pointers how I might go about this?

messages.text: Did i miss the JuMP-dev 2021 ? It was supposed to happen in January this year according to <https://jump.dev/jump-dev/2020/04/15/jump_dev_2020_cancellation/>

attachments.title: Cancelled: JuMP-dev 2020
attachments.text: First, we hope that everyone is safe in these uncertain times. Our first priority will always be the health and well-being of the JuMP community. Therefore, we regret to announce that we have decided to cancel JuMP-dev 2020. Even though there are conceivable scenarios in which travel restrictions are lifted in Europe before June 15th, we feel that there would not be sufficient time to organize the conference, nor for attendees to book their travel with certainty. However, JuMP-dev 2021 is just around the corner! It will be held in January, 2021 (exact dates TBD) in conjunction with the University of South Florida, in Tampa, Florida. More details to follow. Finally, we will not let the summer pass us by! We are very close to releasing JuMP 1.0. Therefore, we plan on holding a series of weekend coding sprints through the late-spring and summer, with the view to releasing JuMP 1.0 in the fall. Further details of these sprints will be announced in due course, but I invite you all to contribute to the final development of JuMP 1.0!

messages.text:
I want to minimize 1/2 Abs[-x2 y1 + x3 y1 + x1 y2 - x3 y2 - x1 y3 + x2 y3] subject to 700kb of constraint in text form. The constraint uses &&, ||, <=, >=. != on sums of multinomials over the 6 variables mentioned above. I know that optimal values are irrational.
Is there any tool in Julia i could use to call this. I know there are multiple identical glocabl minimas.
The constraints.

files.name: constraint.txt
files.title: constraint
files.preview_highlight:
-(x2*y1) + x3*y1 + x1*y2 - x3*y2 - x1*y3 + x2*y3 != 0 && 
 (-(x3*y1) + x1*y3 <= 0 || -(x2*y1) + x3*y1 + x1*y2 - x3*y2 - x1*y3 + 
    x2*y3 <= 0) && (-(x2*y1) + x1*y2 >= 0 || 
  -(x2*y1) + x3*y1 + x1*y2 - x3*y2 - x1*y3 + x2*y3 <= 0) && 
 (-(x3*y2) + x2*y3 >= 0 || -(x2*y1) + x3*y1 + x1*y2 - x3*y2 - x1*y3 +

```
#Gurobi code 

function my_callback_function(cb_data, cb_where::Cint)
        
         if cb_where != GRB_CB_MIPSOL && cb_where != GRB_CB_MIPNODE
             return
         end
         if cb_where == GRB_CB_MIPNODE
             resultP = Ref{Cint}()
             GRBcbget(cb_data, cb_where, GRB_CB_MIPNODE_STATUS, resultP)
             if resultP[] != GRB_OPTIMAL
                 return  # Solution is something other than optimal.
             end
         end
        if cb_where == GRB_CB_MIPSOL

function my_callback_function(cb_data)
    reason = GLPK.glp_ios_reason(cb_data.tree)  
 push!(reasons, reason)
if reason != GLPK.GLP_IROWGEN

messages.text: it's probably a little to early to start undertaking a major effort, but have you guys considered implementing SymbolicUtils.jl on top of the JuMP algebra?  could have some exciting applications with Symbolics.jl coming around.  It shouldn't take much work to implement the interface, though I'm not sure what the longer term prospects are for it, my main concern is that if there is much overlap between the kinds of simplifications that you'd do with Symbolics and functionality that JuMP already implements, it might be a lot of work to rewrite stuff

elements.text: it's probably a little to early to start undertaking a major effort, but have you guys considered implementing SymbolicUtils.jl on top of the JuMP algebra?  could have some exciting applications with Symbolics.jl coming around.  It shouldn't take much work to implement the interface, though I'm not sure what the longer term prospects are for it, my main concern is that if there is much overlap between the kinds of simplifications that you'd do with Symbolics and functionality that JuMP already implements, it might be a lot of work to rewrite stuff

messages.text: The way forward for this is probably to write a SymbolicUtils->MOI layer. At this point, JuMP is basically just a nice user-interface to MOI, and if we can remove JuMP's macro complexity in favor of something else, we'd be all ears.

text.text: The way forward for this is probably to write a SymbolicUtils->MOI layer. At this point, JuMP is basically just a nice user-interface to MOI, and if we can remove JuMP's macro complexity in favor of something else, we'd be all ears.

messages.text: SymbolicUtils already has an MOI layer almost done

elements.text: SymbolicUtils already has an MOI layer almost done

messages.text: Why would you not just use it?
